thread.title: Why Worldcoin Registration Will Resume in Kenya after Police Investigations
thread.title_full: Why Worldcoin Registration Will Resume in Kenya after Police Investigations

author: Japhet Ruto
title: Why Worldcoin Registration Will Resume in Kenya after Police Investigations
text:
Worldcoin Returning to Kenya as Police Drop Investigations, to Resume Registration of Users
- President William Ruto's government suspended Worldcoin activities after it scanned the eyeballs of over 350,000 Kenyans
- David Njoka, the head of cyber-security standards and policy, warned that the data collected from unsuspecting citizens was not safe
- Cybersecurity expert Allan Lwala told TUKO.co.ke that the entity's free coins are cryptocurrencies and could breach the privacy of biometric collection
PAY ATTENTION:

TUKO.co.ke journalist Japhet Ruto brings over eight years of experience in financial,
business, and technology reporting, offering deep insights into Kenyan and global economic trends.
Worldcoin, a
cryptocurrency project by Tools for Humanity, is set to resume operations in Kenya after the police dropped investigations against it.
The government suspended Worldcoin's activities in 2023 over allegations of data privacy breach.
However, in a letter to World Coin's law firm, Coulson Harney, on June 14, the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) revealed the chief prosecutor had closed its file with no further action.
Kenyans Slam Govt after It Warned Against Sharing Ruto, MPs' Phone Numbers Online in Finance Bill Protests

"The resultant investigation file was forwarded to the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions for an independent review and advice. Upon review of the file, the Director of Public Prosecutions concurred and directed that the file be closed with no further police action," the DCI stated as reported by
[Capital FM].
How did Worldcoin breach privacy?
Cybersecurity expert Allan Lwala told TUKO.co.ke that the entity's free coins are cryptocurrencies.
He warned that the tricky part was the collection of iris biometrics.
Lwala argued that this might breach the privacy of Kenyans who are scanning their eyeballs.
"It is an impending privacy nightmare. You can do a lot with the biometric information. Like any cryptocurrency, it's also a bubble that grows thanks to word-of-mouth marketing. We stop talking about it, it pops," Lwala explained.
Why did the government suspend Worldcoin?
In August 2023, the government
suspended Worldcoin activities, requiring Kenyans to scan their eyeballs to get KSh 7,000.
Interior Cabinet Secretary (CS)
Kithure Kindiki said the entity's activities would remain terminated until relevant authorities proved its authenticity regarding data privacy.
Over 350,000 Kenyans
had scanned their eyeballs for the cryptocurrency-free coins.
Are Kenyans' data safe?
The National Assembly Committee investigating Worldcoin operations in
Kenya kicked off the inquiry on Tuesday, August 29, 2023.
The Office of the Director of Computer and Cyber Crime revealed to the committee that since November 2022, the cryptocurrency firm engaged 11 companies in Kenya.
The head of cyber-security standards and policy, David Njoka, warned that the data collected from the 350,000 Kenyans was unsafe.

Ruto graduated from Moi University in 2015 with a Bachelor’s Degree in Communication and Journalism. He is a Business & Tech Editor. Ruto won the 2019 BAKE Awards’ Agriculture Blog of the Year. He was named TUKO.co.ke's best current affairs editor in 2020 and 2021. In 2022 and 2023, he was TUKO.co.ke's best business editor.
